Late reply, but you can actually propose the GI date even in background processing by entering the date in the screen field IT_WTIST-LOW (“Act. Gds Mvmnt Date”).

However, when you execute it in foreground, it doesn’t seem to work but if you run it in background, it behaves as expected.

More details, check SAP Note 3066990 – VL06G: Actual GI date (WADAT_IST) in background posting

Kind regards,
Renan Sassi

entry.title: Triggering next production operation in MES after subcontracting receipt with quality inspection
entry.content:
Hello everyone,
I’m currently working on an S/4HANA Manufacturing project, where we have a complex subcontracting flow that integrates PP, QM, EWM, and MES.

Here’s the process we have defined so far:

  1. A production order (PO) includes two subcontracting operations:

    • Operation 30 (service) → Represents the subcontracted activity itself (the external service).
      → This operation generates an automatic purchase requisition.

    • Operation 35 (Log) → Represents the logistical flow for sending and receiving the parts to/from the subcontractor.
      → This operation also generates an automatic purchase requisition (Log) for the physical goods movement.

  2. Once the subcontracted part is received, it goes into Quality Inspection (Q-stock).

  3. After the Usage Decision (UD) (321 movement from Q → unrestricted), the part becomes available again and must be consumed in the next internal operation (e.g., operation 40).

The main challenge:

After the subcontracted part is received (and still under QM inspection), the two subcontracting operations (30/35) are automatically set to status “External Activity Delivered.”

However, the MES and operators on the shop floor must know when the part is released from QM (after UD) so that they can:

  • Start the next internal production operation (40) in the MES,

  • Trigger the material staging (servi) for operation 40 only when the part is truly available (unrestricted use).

We’re looking for a standard or best practice to automatically trigger the start or readiness of the next operation in MES (or staging in EWM) after the QM Usage Decision.

What we’ve considered:

  • Triggering via the operation confirmation of Presta/Log (not reliable).

  • Triggering via PO confirmation from the subcontractor (too early).

  • Triggering via the Usage Decision (321) — seems the most logical event.
    → But we’re unsure how to best synchronize this with the MES interface (MAN_107_I_023 or equivalent).
    → We also considered linking the 321 event to an automatic stock posting in EWM to stage the part for the next operation.

What we are looking for:

Has anyone already implemented this type of Manufacturing + QM + MES integration for subcontracted parts?
How did you handle the event-based trigger between the Usage Decision and the MES availability signal?
Any standard S/4HANA feature that could cover this ?

Any reference, blog, or customer experience would be greatly appreciated

entry.title: Re: Image / Picture Upload in Material master and visible...

entry.title: Re: Error of ME807
entry.content:
Hello Rathod,

Your PO is saving but not displaying due to a number range issue in the Purchase Info Record (ME11), causing the “Express Document Update was cancelled” error. Fixing the number range and disabling Info Update can resolve it.

Please find below the steps to resolve the issue.

What i analyize with your issue the root cause is, the error “Express Document Update was cancelled” typically occurs when you have below mentioned problems.

1. The number range for Purchase Info Record (PIR) is exhausted.
2. The system tries to update PIR during PO creation (ME21N), but fails due to missing or full number range.
3. Even though the PO number is generated, it doesn’t appear in reports like ME2M.

To fix the issue please follow the steps i mentioned below.

1. Check Number Range for PIR Document Types (IL & IN)
Go to transaction SNRO or SNUM:
Object: EINA (for Info Record)
Check if the number range assigned to document types IL and IN is exhausted.
If yes, create a new number range and assign it to these document types.

2. Disable Info Update During PO Creation
In ME21N, uncheck the box labeled “Info Update”:
This prevents the system from trying to update the PIR.
You can still save the PO without triggering the error.


3. Verify in SM13
Check transaction SM13 for update termination logs:
Client = * (your client)
User = * (your user ID)
Status = ALL
Look for the failed update and confirm it’s related to PIR.

4. Test PO Creation Again
Try creating the PO again with “Info Update” unchecked.
If successful, the PO should now appear in ME2M or ME23N.

Hope this have resolve your issue.

entry.title: Re: How to handle “usernames”, “Global User IDs” and “external IDs” in your landscape?
entry.content:
Hi,

I once looked into whether the Global User ID should be configured as a subject name identifier (SNI), as there are different opinions on that. From what I found, it was previously recommended to set the Global User ID as the SNI because it wasn’t yet supported as a claim in the token. At the time, this was the only way to later use it as a correlation attribute—for example, in SAP Task Center scenarios. With current support for Global User ID in the token, this setup is no longer necessary.

Would be happy to hear any expert thoughts on this.

Best regards,

Ivelina

entry.title: Re: Has Devtoberfest just proved that ABAP is in fact dead?
entry.content:
Hi Thomas,

the sessions are around new stuff and this is definitely the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model also called RAP.

Here the data modelling is based on CDS views and hence CDS views are an important topic for ABAP developers that want to be up to date.  

All new developments in SAP S/4HANA are nowadays based on RAP and hence it is crucial for you as a developer that you know about RAP because even if you want to extend a RAP business object that has been delivered by SAP you have to know the RAP basics.  

And this is true for SAP S/4HANA public cloud as well as for SAP S/4HANA private cloud and the on premise version.   

ABAP Cloud does not mean that the ABAP code runs in the cloud. It is the programming model that allows you to write code that is cloud ready (and thus stable by definition) and which should also be used for new developments in on premise systems.

So if you want to be relevant as an ABAP developer I strongly suggest to have a look at this topics.  

Kind regards,

Andre

entry.title: More Efficiency in HR: Implementing the OpenText Employee File for SAP SuccessFactors the Right Way
entry.content:
Digital employee files have become one of the key pillars of modern HR transformation. They simplify administrative processes, ensure compliance, and relieve both HR teams and employees.

However, for many organizations, the standard capabilities of SAP SuccessFactors are not sufficient when it comes to powerful document management and automated document creation.

That’s where OpenText, the global leader in Enterprise Content Management (ECM), comes in and this blog should help companies make their implementation successful.

More Than Just Document Storage – OpenText for SAP SuccessFactors

With the Solution Extension “#SAP SuccessFactors Document Management Core by OpenText,” companies gain access to a modern, cloud-native solution that takes document management and document generation to the next level.

The solution consists of two core components:

  • Digital Employee File powered by OpenText Core Content Management
  • Document Generation Service powered by OpenText Core Communications

These services integrate seamlessly with key SuccessFactors modules such as Employee Central, Recruiting, and Onboarding, enabling end-to-end HR processes without media disruptions.

Key Success Factors for a Successful Implementation

Introducing a digital employee file is not merely an IT project – it’s a strategic transformation toward a more efficient and future-proof HR operation.
Based on numerous customer projects, five key success factors have proven decisive:

1. Make an Early Decision on the File Structure of the HR file

During project preparation, it’s essential to decide whether a customized file structure will be developed or an existing one adopted.

Alternatively, companies can leverage best-practice structures provided by experienced implementation partners, built on the requirements and lessons learned from numerous HR projects. These usually have proven highly reliable and cost-efficient in real-world scenarios.

A change of the structures and file plan later can cause expensive change requests, so rather take the time to find the best approach.

2. A Consistent Strategy for International Rollouts

When rolling out global HR programs, consistency pays off in the long run.

The OpenText Employee File offers a Global HR file template – a master blueprint that serves as the foundation for all employee files.

In multinational or multilingual environments, it’s crucial to decide early whether local requirements (e.g. translations, permissions, or legal fields) can be handled within the global template, or if a local variant is needed.

In practice, integrating local needs into one global template typically proves worthwhile. Fewer templates mean less maintenance, lower complexity, and significantly reduced operating costs.

3. A Thoughtful Permission Concept

A robust and well-designed permission model is one of the cornerstones of success.

Rather than maintaining individual roles in OpenText, it’s recommended to leverage SAP SuccessFactors Role-Based Permissions (RBP) for synchronization between the systems. This ensures consistent and efficient access control across the entire HR landscape.

Permissions should primarily be assigned at folder level, not at document level – this approach minimizes administrative overhead.
Document-level permissions can still be applied in special cases but should remain the exception.

4. Document Generation as an Efficiency Booster
Many companies underestimate the benefits of integrated document generation – yet it’s one of the strongest drivers of efficiency.

Automating the creation of standard documents such as employment contracts, certificates, or official letters saves time, reduces errors, and ensures consistent communication.
With all relevant employee data seamlessly pulled directly from SuccessFactors, the days of copying and pasting names, salaries, or job titles will finally be gone.

For HR teams, that translates to: less manual effort, higher quality, and greater employee satisfaction.

5. Leverage the Full Product Functionality
Beyond its core capabilities, the OpenText solution offers several powerful features that are often overlooked:

  • External document sharing (e.g., with former employees or auditors)
  • Employee self-services for generating certificates or viewing their own records
  • Workflow automation for review and approval processes
  • Office Online integration for seamless editing in the browser

These features not only increase efficiency but also drive user adoption and overall satisfaction.

Conclusion: Structure, Standards, and Smart Features Drive Success

Implementing the OpenText Employee File for SAP SuccessFactors is a crucial step toward achieving true digital HR excellence.

By making clear early decisions about structure, authorization, and functionality, organizations lay the groundwork for a sustainable, future-proof solution.

With the right strategy, what begins as an IT initiative becomes a real business enabler – turning the digital employee file into a cornerstone of modern, efficient, and compliant HR operations.

entry.title: Re: How to Load Non-Refunded Container Deposit Amount to...
entry.content:
Hello Abdul Rafay,
To handle partial container deposit refunds in SAP S/4HANA and load the non-refunded amount to inventory cost, the recommended approach is to use Subsequent Debit via MIRO or Freight Condition Types in the PO.

following are the best practices and configuration steps to replicate your legacy ERP logic in SAP S/4HANA:

My Recommendation for SAP S/4HANA Process Flow

1. Advance Payment Handling
Use F-48 to record the down payment to the vendor.
Use F-54 to clear the down payment during invoice posting.
Then Alternatively, post to a dedicated clearing account for container deposits.

2. Refund Processing
When the refund is received:
Use F-28 or Bank Statement processing to post the incoming payment.
Clear against the container deposit account.
If partial refund is received:
Post the actual refund amount.
Leave the remaining balance in the container deposit account for adjustment.

Loading Non-Refunded Amount to Inventory
Option A
Subsequent Debit via MIRO
Use MIRO with reference to the original PO or material document.
Post a Subsequent Debit entry:
Assign a cost element linked to the inventory valuation class.
Debit the Raw Material Stock GL.
Credit the Container Deposit account.
This increases the inventory value and updates the Moving Average Price (MAP).

Option B
Freight/Custom Condition in PO
Define a custom freight condition type (e.g., ZDEP) in PO pricing schema.
Post the actual cost via MIRO when the deduction is known.
This ensures the cost flows to inventory via GR/IR clearing.

To configure please find below details.
Account Determination: Ensure the cost element used in MIRO is mapped to the correct inventory GL via OBYC settings.

Condition Type Setup: For freight/custom charges, configure condition types in MM pricing schema and link them to inventory valuation.

For audit trail: Both methods provide traceability and comply with audit requirements.

Journal Entries

ScenarioDebitCredit
Advance RecordingContainer DepositClearing Account (Vendor)
Advance PaymentClearing Account (Vendor)Bank Account
Full RefundBank AccountContainer Deposit
Partial RefundBank AccountContainer Deposit
Non-Refund AdjustmentRaw Material Stock GLContainer Deposit

Hope this have solve the purpose. If yes please respond

entry.title: Re: SAP_Transfer Project Special Project Stock (Q) Betwee...
entry.content:
One option is use movement type 351Q (goods issue from supplying plant) and 101 Q (goods receipt in receiving plant). Best suited when you want traceability, planning, and logistics integration. You need to trigger inbound delivery or transport costs.

The other option is transfer via 301Q which transfers unrestricted-use project stock from one plant to another. It’s a one-step transfer, simpler and faster. No need for PO or delivery documents. Best suited when you want a quick internal transfer without procurement steps. No need for logistics tracking or intercompany billing.

entry.title: Re: Capture ATC Errors for CDS Views Without Released API State
entry.content:
Hi @MohanKumar5 ,

ABAP_CLOUD_READINESS ATC variant and clean core checks based ATC variant support two different ATC checks procedure: the first one checks ABAP Cloud readiness and the second one clean core readiness. You need to decide which check procedure you want to apply and don't mix the checks as on your screenshot.

Now to your case. Your not-released custom wrapper CDS view ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC is in the package with "Standard ABAP" language version. If then your ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC_CLD CDS view is located in the ABAP package with ABAP for Cloud Development language version and  using the ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC, then you should get the syntax error, because it is using the not-released CDS view. If it does not happen, then please open a ticket to SAP to process this issue. If your ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC_CLD CDS view is located in the ABAP package with "Standard ABAP" language version and is using the ZI_RERENTALOBJECT_POC, you will not get any ATC error with clean core ATC checks.

Kind Regards,
Olga.

entry.title: Re: passing prompt values from a story to a data insight
entry.content:
From your screenshot, it looks like you want to pass a range to a variable value. This is not currently possible with URL parameters. There is an Improvement Request to implement this, which has been accepted, and the last update is that it will come in the Q4 release. 

For now, you can only pass single values or multiple values. Depending on what you are trying to achieve exactly, and what control you have over the solution, you could adjust your BW Query to rely on separate From and To variables. You could also perhaps build an array of dates for the full range and pass these as multiple values, but it is not very scalable, and you may rapidly run into URL character length limits or related problems.

The best workaround for now, if you just want to open the query in Data Analyser (not specifically a saved insight) would be to call the openDataAnalyzer() method on a table using the live model in your Story. This will pass the range variable values to data analyser without you needing to script anything else. The drill state of the resulting insight will mimic the drill state of the table in the story, and all variable vaules as well as filter values will be passed also. It also passes the context, so if the end user saves an insight from the resulting data analyser view, they will also have the option to Save and Pin the insight to the source widget, so that they can come back to it again directly from the same story (pinned insights are user-specific, users will only see their own pinned insights).

If you wanted the insight to be in a different navigational state, then you could use a hidden table with a pre-configured navigation state, and call openDataAnalyzer() on the hidden table.

Cheers, Ivan.

entry.title: BW/4HANA connection to SuccessFactors using Compoundemployee soap API instead Odata API
entry.content:
Hello Team,

W want use Compoundemployee soap API instead Odata API instead of SF Odata API to connect BW/4HANA to SuccessFactors using the DP agent.

the reason is : OdataAdapter required for SF Odata API is not supported any more to run on the DP agent and it has to run in DP server in SAP HANA Database. meantime the direct connection from SAP HANA DB to SF is not allowed and it has to be through DP agent installed in a separate machine.

the DP agent , we can use SoapAdapter and use Compoundemployee Soap API instead to extract data from SF to BW/4HANA.

Appreciate your confirmation if we can use Soap API instead of OData API please  to connect BW/4HANA to SuccessFactors through SAP Data Provisioning Agent

entry.title: Guidelines for content created with generative AI
entry.content:
Use of generative AI in the SAP Community

Generative AI tools can be useful for organizing ideas or improving posts, but they can also blur the line between genuine personal contributions and machine-written text. We need to maintain a community where content reflects real experience, authentic voices, and trusted expertise.

These guidelines are meant to ensure that AI can be used responsibly without diminishing the value or confidence in member-created content. We think the the acceptable and unacceptable guidelines below strike a balance between using the power of generative AI to maintaining an authors own knowledge, perspective and voice.

What counts as "content created by generative AI"?

“Content generated by generative AI” refers to any content created, in whole or in part, using a system that automatically generates content in response to a prompt. Examples of systems include large language models such as ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude or open source models. While these tools are designed to produce text that sounds natural and convincing, the accuracy and quality of their output can vary widely including completely fabricated content due to hallucination.

Why a policy on generative AI?

To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology.

 

What are acceptable uses of generative AI?

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as “This post was assisted by GenAI.” For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 



What are unacceptable uses of generative AI?

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to “polish” a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

 

What happens if I don't follow these guidelines?

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author’s stated intent.

Furthermore, if a post appears to violate the acceptable use criteria, it will likely be removed along with any points or reputation it gained. Continued abuse of generative AI tools may result in moderator warnings or, for repeated violations, account suspensions or permanent bans. 

What if I am new but I still want to contribute?

All of our top contributors started with no SAP knowledge, and many built their reputations by providing answers in the community. One approach is to look for an unanswered question in a technology you are familiar with (especially one with a high view count), do some research and see if you can come up with a solution. You will learn during this process and help other community members at the same time.

 

Much like generative AI tools that are always evolving, this policy will need to evolve and be updated as unforeseen usages of generative AI require fast moderation reactions that may or may not be reflected just in time in this document, but the moderators are empowered to enforce as needed any and all steps to protect the experience of our SAP Community members as directed by management.

entry.title: Protecting the integrity of the community content
entry.content:
Generative AI tools can be powerful aids when used thoughtfully, offering speed and inspiration, but they can also produce misleading or inaccurate results if applied without real expertise. Their value comes from being trained on years of human-created knowledge, yet that is also why our community must be careful in how they are applied.

Workflows are shifting as users adopt more efficient ways to get the information needed to complete their tasks.
But one thing remains constant: people come to our community because they trust the answers, posts, and discussions written by fellow members. To preserve that trust and ensure our content remains reliable, we need clear, shared guidelines on the responsible use of generative AI within our community. 

The slippery slope

At first glance, protecting content integrity by banning all GenAI-assisted content generation may seem a simple choice. But that would ignore the fact that GenAI can be a powerful aid in creating content (it even played a role in drafting this). The trick is developing guidelines that lets users take advantage of these tools to enhance their productivity. Consider this scenario:

About 75% of traffic in our community happens in the Q&A/Forums section, where people come looking for solutions to specific problems. The traditional workflow has looked something like this:

  • You run into a problem and start with a Google search.
  • From the results, you open a handful of promising pages, read through them, and piece together enough information to solve your issue or at least get enough of a hint.
  • If that doesn’t work, you post a question. If your post doesn’t include enough detail, there’s a back-and-forth in the comments until someone can provide a solid answer. That process may take time.

With generative AI, the workflow shifts:

  • You may still search as before.
  • More often, you open your preferred generative AI tool, start with a quick prompt, invest more time in writing a prompt if needed, and engage in a rapid back-and-forth until you get a usable answer or enough direction to move forward. In practice, the tool is drawing on nearly all available content at once.
  • If you still don’t get what you need, only then might you open a new question or discussion thread.

With this as a standard workflow now and access to many geneartive AI tools, it is tempting to take any unanswered question, paste it into a GenAI tool, copy the response and paste in the answer. The danger here is if the person posting the answer doesn’t actually know if it is correct or not.
This creates two problems if the answer is wrong:

  1. the original poster will believe it to be correct, try it, wasting their time and diminishing the perceived value of the community.
  2. if incorrect data remains in the community, it will be scraped by the generative AI models, used in their training or RAG systems, decreasing the quality of answers (until it is removed).

This community exists to share knowledge and experience between real people. AI tools cannot ensure accuracy, provide verifiable sources, or account for the nuances of real-world problem solving. Allowing AI-authored posts without the author verifying the content risks:

  • Spreading incorrect or misleading information.
  • Eroding the trust between members.
  • Diminishing the long-term value of our content.

Acceptable use of generative AI tools

You may use GenAI tools to help you plan, structure, or clarify your writing, as long as the final result reflects your own thoughts and tone.

Examples include:

  • Outlining your post or drafting a structure to build upon
  • Checking spelling, translation, or accessibility
  • Getting suggestions for phrasing, while keeping your own wording and perspective

If a generative AI tool meaningfully shaped your post (anything beyond the examples above like rewriting full paragraphs or producing a significant amount of the text), please disclose it by adding the predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label, or include a short note such as “This post was assisted by GenAI.” For content where it's not possible to add a user tag, e.g., answers to questions and comments, you must include this statement: "This post was assisted by GenAI."

Doing so will provide the transparency needed to maintain credibility in the community.

A predefined "GenAI Assisted Content" label can now be found throughout the community: 


Unacceptable use of generative AI tools

Posts that are primarily generated, rewritten, or reworded by AI are not allowed.

Examples include:

  • Submitting AI-generated answers to questions or forum threads
  • Submitting AI-generated articles or comments to content as your own
  • Using AI to “polish” a post so heavily that it loses your natural voice
  • Copying or pasting AI text directly from a prompt
  • Publishing content with little or no personal input or factual verification

Moderators may remove posts that read as machine-written or lack personal insight, regardless of the author’s stated intent.

A TLDR summary (intentionally at the end) or guiding principle is:

Anything you post in the community should represent your thinking, experience, and knowledge.
AI may assist you in the creation, but it cannot substitute for your voice. 
To keep your trust and add continual value to our members we must remain a community of people, for people, in our shared world of technology. 

The complete generative AI guidelines for the SAP Community can be found in our Welcome Corner group.

entry.title: Re: Posting of Recognized Revenue for Cost‑Based Percenta...
entry.content:
Hello @summy

Have a look at https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/89d896ca9cd64318b1667df5ec00e4b2/7fd9ad1108b94403a2871cf348d4b891.html?locale=en-US for more details.

In summary, based on the details and screenshots you provided, the system has calculated correctly as it was designed.

The reason is, when Recognised Revenue equal 0 JPY, it means the Planned Revenue has not been maintained in the project plan data. The cost-based POC method requires both planned Cost and Planned Revenue values to calculate and post recognised revenue.

Mathematically, this means POC equals 50% but then 50% multiplied by 0 Planned Revenue equals 0.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: How to configure a number range of material number in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
entry.content:
What is the way to configure a range of material number on a tenant of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to configure a number range of material number in...
entry.content:
Hello team,

To configure the internal and external number ranges for products/materials, you can use the Configuration Activity/SSCUI 102282 "Define Number Ranges for Each Material Type".
This configuration activity is located in the following IMG path: Logistics - General > Material Master > Basic Settings > Material Types > Define Number Ranges for Each Material Type.

If you encounter any issues while attempting to update the number ranges, I recommend reading this helpful blog post:

  • How does number ranges work in Product Master SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud? | SAP Community.

It provides detailed explanations of common errors and their resolutions.

Kind Regards,
Ícaro
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Impact of a U.S. Federal Government Shutdown on E-Verify
entry.content:
Here's the official notification I received this morning, 9 October 2025, "E-Verify Resumes Operations":

Creating Cases

Employers who participate in E‑Verify must create an E‑Verify case by Tuesday, Oct. 14 for each employee hired while E‑Verify was not available. You must use the hire date from the employee’s Form I‑9 when creating the E‑Verify case. If you could not create an E‑Verify case by the third business day after the employee began work for pay because E‑Verify was unavailable, E‑Verify will prompt you during case creation to provide a reason for the delay. Select “Other” from the “Select a Reason for Delay” drop-down menu and enter “E‑Verify not Available” as the specific reason in the “Reason for Delay” text box. The days E‑Verify was unavailable will not count toward the three business days employers usually have to create a case in E-Verify.

Tentative Nonconfirmations (Mismatches)

If your employee received a mismatch and notified you of their intention to contest it, and you provided the Referral Date Confirmation to the employee, you must revise the date by which your employee must contact the Social Security Administration (SSA) or the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to begin resolving the mismatch. You have three options to provide a revised date to your employee(s) for their “Referral Date Confirmation” notice:

  • The best option is to print a new “Referral Date Confirmation” notice that will have the new date employees must contact SSA or DHS to begin resolving their mismatch. To reprint a copy of your employee’s “Referral Date Confirmation,” log in to E‑Verify, select your employee’s case, and select the “Print Confirmation” button.
  • The next option is to log in to E‑Verify, select the employee’s case to find their new referral date, and write the new date on the previously issued “Referral Date Confirmation” notice.
  • The third option is to add six (6) federal business days to the date on your employee’s “Referral Date Confirmation” notice. Federal business days are Monday through Friday and do not include federal holidays.

For mismatch cases that were referred once E‑Verify resumed operations on or after Oct. 8, 2025, do not add days to the time your employee has to contact either SSA or DHS. If your employee decided to contest the mismatch when E‑Verify was unavailable, you should now refer the employee’s case and follow the mismatch process.

Federal Contractor Deadlines

During E‑Verify’s unavailability, federal contractors could not enroll or use E‑Verify as required by the E‑Verify federal contractor rule. As a result, any calendar day when E‑Verify was unavailable will not count toward any of the federal contractor deadlines. Please contact your contracting officer, as necessary, for more information on federal contractor responsibilities.

Employees with traditional E‑Verify cases

If the unavailability of E‑Verify prevented you from contesting your mismatch, we will give you additional time to contact SSA or DHS to begin the process of resolving your mismatch. If you received a “Referral Date Confirmation” notice indicating you must take action by Oct. 1, 2025 or later, you have three options to obtain your new date:

  • Contact your employer and have them print out a new “Referral Date Confirmation” notice for you. Your notice will have the new date you must contact the SSA or DHS to begin resolving your mismatch.
  • A second option is to ask your employer to log in to E‑Verify to get your new referral date and write the new date on your previously issued “Referral Date Confirmation” notice.
  • Or you may add six (6) federal business days to the date printed on the “Referral Date Confirmation” that your employer provided you after you contested your mismatch. Federal business days are Monday through Friday and do not include federal holidays.

Contact either SSA or DHS by the new date to begin the process of resolving your mismatch.

For more information, please visit E-Verify's "How to Process a Mismatch" page.

If you want to integrate with SAP Commerce and simplify integration development, you can use a ready-made solution like API2Cart. It provides a unified API, so you can easily connect to SAP Commerce and other eCommerce platforms at once. You will be able to get, add, update and sync store data such as orders, products, customers, etc. 

Save your time and resources and focus on other business goals while API2Cart takes care of integrations.

KR Maria

entry.title: Re: Project System - Scheduling
entry.content:
You mentioned “Finish Not Later Than” — this constraint can override backward scheduling logic. If the constraint is set as a hard constraint, SAP may schedule all activities to start as early as possible to ensure compliance. Try changing it to a soft constraint or test without it to see if dates adjust.

Ensure the network header is set to backward scheduling. In CJ20N, go to the network → Dates tab → check “Scheduling Type.” If it’s set to forward or not defined, SAP will default to earliest dates.

Check the work calendar assigned to the network and activities. If the calendar includes weekends as working days, SAP will schedule continuously. Use SCAL to verify calendar settings.

Run CJ24N or CN24 to trigger overall network scheduling. This recalculates earliest and latest dates based on constraints and relationships.

entry.title: Why Preliminary billing document rejected by workflow requires an additional rejection?
entry.content:
Hello,

In S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1, I'm rejecting a preliminary billing document via the Fiori App F2875, its status becomes Rejected (and Approval Status is not relevant because the document was not finalized/no workflow started):

 

I can then immediately create a new preliminary billing document, etc.

So far, so good.

If I finalize a preliminary billing document, it enters the approval flexible workflow (WS02000042), then I reject it (via the workflow), its Status is still "Finalized" and there's an additional "Approval Status" with value "Rejected" in F2874:

The only thing I can do with this document, I think, is to reject it via F2875 without the workflow as shown first (and create a new preliminary billing document, etc.) It's not possible to "Set to In Progress" (error because it has gone through the workflow process).

After rejecting via the workflow, can something be done other than rejecting? If no, why isn't the document fully rejected, in one go?

Thank you.

Sandra

PS: for information:

Reference documents in SAP Help Portal: Manage Preliminary Billing Documents and Approval Workflows for Preliminary Billing Documents (in SAP S/4HANA > Sales > Order and Contract Management > Sales Billing > Billing Processing > Preliminary Billing Documents).

The "Status" is stored in VBRK-PBD_STATUS:

  • 'B': finalized
  • 'D': rejected

The "Approval Status" is stored in VBRK-APM_APPROVAL_STATUS:

  • 'B': approved
  • 'C': rejected

entry.title: Does version management for purchase contract require flexible workflow setup?
entry.content:
Hello, I would like to set up version management for purchase contract which will be created via Manage Purchase Contract F1600A app (SAP S/4HANA 2023, On-premise). I am going through the menu below to set it up, but versioning is not triggered.

If I do the setup via the 'old' menu, i.e. Set Up Version Management for External Purchasing Documents, I get the versions generated (for changes via the app and also GUI), but Manage Purchase Contract app is still not showing the Version history tab.

I am wondering what is the right way to set up versioning for documents using the app. Do I have to set up a workflow?

I saw in SAP documentation that I have to 'Ensure the flexible workflow is activated before enabling versioning for purchase contracts.'

On the other hand, SAP note 3252885 says: 'Version management is not integrated completely with flexible workflow in MM Purchasing Business Objects such as PO, PR, Contracts, etc. It has not been considered in the integration as many MM Purchasing Fiori apps such as ‘Manage Purchase Orders’ does not support the classic version management..' 

So, I am a bit confused which one is the right way...

Regards,

Roumi

entry.title: "In every number, a narrative unfolds."
entry.content:
In today’s fast-evolving business landscape, the role of financial statements has transformed from merely being compliance documents to strategic tools that drive business decisions. For professionals, especially in high-growth sectors like technology, real-time and integrated reporting is crucial for maintaining a competitive edge.

 

Understanding how financial statements connect is fundamental to managing business performance. While many perceive the Income Statement, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow Statement as separate reports, they are in fact deeply interconnected. Each offers a unique lens on business health — profitability, financial position, and liquidity — yet the true insight emerges only when one understands how they flow into one another.

The visual framework popularized by Brian Feroldi provides a clear and intuitive demonstration of how numbers travel across these statements and how every financial decision leaves its footprint throughout the reporting structure.

 

 

 

The Income Statement – Measuring Profitability

The Income Statement (or Profit & Loss Statement) captures a company’s performance over a given period. It records revenues, costs, and expenses to show whether the company operated profitably.

In the example shown:

  • Revenue increases from $100,000 to $120,000, indicating business growth.
  • Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) rises from $50,000 to $55,000, slightly reducing gross profit.
  • Operating Expenses move from $25,000 to $30,000, showing higher overhead or investment in capability.
  • Depreciation of $10,000 remains a non-cash charge but still impacts reported profit.
  • Net Income improves from $15,000 to $22,500, feeding directly into both the Cash Flow Statement and the Shareholders’ Equity section of the Balance Sheet.

The Income Statement provides the first key input into how the company’s performance translates into its financial position.

The Balance Sheet – Capturing Financial Position

The Balance Sheet provides a snapshot at a point in time — what the company owns (assets), owes (liabilities), and retains (equity).

Let’s look at how the data connects:

  • Cash drops from $70,000 to $7,500, reflecting total outflows from operations, investing, and financing activities.
  • Receivables decrease from $25,000 to $20,000, improving cash collection and liquidity.
  • Inventory increases from $10,000 to $15,000, consuming cash as the company builds stock.
  • Property, Plant & Equipment expands from $140,000 to $180,000, representing capital expenditure.
  • Shareholders’ Equity grows from $105,000 to $127,500, driven by retained earnings from the Income Statement.

Every change on the Balance Sheet corresponds to a business event — cash collected, inventory purchased, assets invested, or profits retained — and each of these has a direct impact on the Cash Flow Statement.

The Cash Flow Statement – Explaining Liquidity

The Cash Flow Statement bridges the gap between profitability (Income Statement) and position (Balance Sheet). It translates accrual accounting into actual cash movements, showing whether a company’s operations truly generate or consume cash.

Here’s how the example unfolds:

  • Net Income of $22,500 flows in from the Income Statement.
  • Depreciation of $5,000 is added back since it’s a non-cash charge.
  • Inventory increase of $5,000 consumes cash, while a $5,000 drop in Receivables releases cash.
  • Capital Expenditures of $50,000 appear under Investing Activities, reducing available cash.
  • Changes in Debt (-$35,000) reflect loan repayments under Financing Activities.

The resulting Change in Cash of ($62,500) reconciles perfectly with the drop in the cash balance on the Balance Sheet.

How the Three Statements Connect

Financial statements do not stand alone — they are dynamically linked.
Here’s how key relationships flow:

Relationship

Flow Between Statements

Impact

Net Income → Retained Earnings

Income Statement → Balance Sheet

Increases equity

Depreciation → Assets & Cash Flow

Income Statement → Cash Flow → Balance Sheet

Reduces profit, but no cash impact

CapEx → PP&E and Cash

Cash Flow → Balance Sheet

Reduces cash, increases long-term assets

Receivables / Payables Changes

Balance Sheet ↔ Cash Flow

Impact working capital and liquidity

Debt & Dividends → Financing Section

Balance Sheet ↔ Cash Flow

Reflect funding and shareholder payouts

This seamless linkage ensures that every recorded transaction has a corresponding and traceable financial impact across all three reports — maintaining integrity and completeness in reporting.

Modernizing Financial Linkages with SAP Group Reporting

In today’s digital finance landscape, these connections are no longer manually tracked — they are automated and reconciled in real time through SAP S/4HANA Group Reporting powered with AI and Narrative Insights

This solution extends the power of the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) — SAP’s single source of truth — by unifying transactional, statutory, and management data across entities.

 

 

Key advantages include:

  • Real-Time Integration: Income Statement, Balance Sheet, and Cash Flow are automatically linked at both entity and group levels.
  • Automated Cash Flow Derivation: Systemically derives cash flow movements from accounting entries (e.g., changes in receivables, payables, assets).
  • Built-In Consolidation: Intercompany eliminations, ownership calculations, and currency translations occur within a unified environment.
  • Transparency and Auditability: Every reported number can be traced back to source entries, enhancing confidence during close and reporting cycles.
  • End-to-End Performance View: Finance leaders can assess profitability, liquidity, and leverage across subsidiaries in one integrated dashboard.

With SAP Group Reporting, the conceptual flow between the three financial statements becomes a real-time digital continuum, enabling CFOs to close faster, report more accurately, and plan more intelligently.

Financial statements are not isolated reports — they form an interconnected system that narrates the complete story of business performance.
Understanding their linkage helps finance professionals interpret not just what happened, but why it happened and how it affects future cash and value.

 Understanding their connections help us see not just what has happened, but why, and what the future may hold. With intelligent tools and clear insight, professionals can turns complex numbers into a narrative that guides company towards smarter decisions and greater success.

Srinath Ganesan

entry.title: Re: The system automatically posts where the EBRR (1a) and (2a) account configuration points are
entry.content: SAP Machine Translation Portal translation: #SAP S/4HANA CLOUD PUBLIC #SAP S4HANA Cloud, public edition Finance#SAP S4HANA Cloud;1K2 - Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Specifications for Posting from Stock During Sales; With the new Event-Based Revenue Recognition - Sell from Stock new feature, the system automatically posts the revenue adjustment upon goods issue (depending on the EBRR key you chose); the system automatically posts the EBRR (1a) and (2a) where the configuration point of the account is located

entry.title: Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable in Product API error
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and trying to perform a POST operation using the Product (API_PRODUCT_2) API.
However, I’m receiving the following error response:

{
  "error": {
    "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
    "message": "Entity PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT is not maintainable",
    "target": "_ProductPurchaseOrderText(Product='102010000009',TextObjectType='BEST',Language='EN')",
    "details": [
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductProcurement"
      },
      {
        "code": "CMD_PROD_RAP/011",
        "message": "Entity PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT is not maintainable",
        "target": "_ProductPlant(Product='102010000009',Plant='CN7A')/_ProductPlantProcurement"
      }
    ],
    "innererror": {
      "ErrorDetails": {
        "@SAP__common.Application": {
          "ComponentId": "LO-MD-MM",
          "ServiceRepository": "SRVD_A2X",
          "ServiceId": "API_PRODUCT_2",
          "ServiceVersion": "0001"
        },
        "@SAP__common.TransactionId": "86545C3DDA130010E0068E7D20C1703B",
        "@SAP__common.Timestamp": "20251009154237.258522",
        "@SAP__common.ErrorResolution": {
          "Analysis": "Use ADT feed reader 'SAP Gateway Error Log' or run transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG on SAP Gateway hub system and search for entries with the timestamp above for more details",
          "Note": "See SAP Note 1797736 for error analysis"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

My Question:

  • Why are these entities (PRODUCTPURCHASEORDERTEXT, PRODUCTPROCUREMENT, PRODUCTPLANTPROCUREMENT) not maintainable through the post API?

  • Are there any restrictions in the Public Cloud Edition for maintaining these sub-entities via API?

  • Is there an alternative API or approach to update these product procurement or purchase order text details?

 

I’ve already checked the payload structure and API reference documentation, and the JSON is valid. The base product entity is being read successfully — the error occurs only during the POST operation.

Any insights or SAP Notes related to this behavior would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance,
Janarthanan R.

entry.title: Comunidade SAP Belo Horizonte – Acompanhe nossas novidades e fique por dentro dos próximos eventos!
entry.content:
Comunidade SAP Belo Horizonte – Acompanhe nossas novidades e fique por dentro dos próximos eventos!

Olá, SAP Community! 👋

Meu nome é Neylon Silva Soares, sou consultor SAP com foco em Cloud Integration (CPI) e atualmente trabalho em projetos internacionais na Europa, em uma das maiores empresas farmacêuticas do continente, referência em boas práticas com SAP Integration Suite.

Com mais de 12 anos de experiência em desenvolvimento e arquitetura SAP (ABAP, BTP, Integration Suite, entre outros), venho dedicando os últimos anos à especialização em SAP Cloud Integration, atuando em projetos globais em empresas como Natura, LVMH, Chesapeake Energy (EUA), Hyve (UK), entre outras.

Sou também líder da Comunidade SAP de Belo Horizonte, onde tenho o prazer de contribuir com a organização de eventos como o SAP Inside Track BH, além de apoiar a produção de conteúdo técnico para nossa comunidade local e global.

A equipe hoje da Comunidade SAP BH é formada por:

  • Neylon Silva
  • Davi Lourenço
  • Tadeu Ribeiro
  • Vinícius Guimarães
  • Cristiano Santos

📚Conhecimento compartilhado

Amo ensinar e compartilhar o que aprendo no dia a dia. Por isso, tenho contribuído com artigos técnicos no Blog da SAP Community, como por exemplo:

  • 🔗DRC NFSe Outbound utilizando Partner Enablement no SAP Public Cloud
  • 🔗HTTP e OData dinâmico no SAP Cloud Integration (CI/CPI)

Também mantenho um canal no YouTube com conteúdos gratuitos sobre:

  • SAP Cloud Integration (CPI)
  • Clean Core
  • Trabalhar com SAP no exterior
  • Carreira SAP e muito mais!

🎥Acesse aqui: Neylon SAP – YouTube

📣Fique ligado!

Se você é de Belo Horizonte ou região (ou mesmo de qualquer lugar do Brasil), siga o Blog da Comunidade SAP Belo Horizonte aqui na SAP Community.

Em breve teremos novidades sobre os próximos eventos presenciais, abertos a toda a comunidade, com muito networking, aprendizado e troca de experiências.

👉Siga também meu perfil no LinkedIn para não perder nenhum anúncio!

Vamos juntos fortalecer ainda mais a Comunidade SAP em BH e no Brasil! 🇧🇷🚀
